review_title: It's about time they raised their stipends.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Montreal, QC
pros: If you find a good supervisor, if you have good financial support from your family and if you have unwavering optimism in succeeding in a sisyphean task, you will find a lot of enjoyment doing research at McGill. You will have access to almost world class laboratories, almost cutting edge equipment and technologies, and almost state-of-the-art facilities. Most importantly, you will work and struggle together with graduate students from diverse backgrounds and experience levels. It will be a learning experience that will hopefully not saddle you with debt and provide you with a pathway to gainful employment.
cons: You will question your own self worth and spend many sleepless nights pondering why you didn't just go and get a Real Job™️. Finding like minded peers outside of your department will be a struggle given the perpetual disarray and dysfunction of most graduate student associations. That is assuming that you are not already swamped with the unforgiving research work and the non-stop whining of undergraduate students who you are babysitting on behalf of an overworked research supervisor. Also do not forget about the overbearing administrative overhead that cocoons everyone in red tape. If only they put more effort on raising the stipend amount, which has not changed in 20 years and counting.

job_title: Customer Service Consultant in Montreal, QC
pros: nice people at your level good work life balance move from within the company is good
cons: pay is low Work structure is disorganized : for accounting purposes, your work name level, designation and definition may be downplayed in order for them to pay you less. This has the combined effect of confusing the lines of how far your responsibilities extend. back stabbing: HR is not involved in culture management and since this is an academic setting, the same values of academia permeate throughout the administrative jobs; in fighting, backstabbing, rumours, and cliques become a problem and everyone has to work to protect themselves from their bosses and other people's bosses. Often, promises will be made and broken on the standpoint of fairness pulling from the bottom. Ex.: you do work above your level, and so, you want to be promoted to this level. But since the work you were doing would garner too high of a salary jump if your title would match your work, you can see yourself being put in a higher position with either, the same title and a derisive improvement in salary; maintained on the same salary but with a higher title; or to just be forced to work like that with no change, while someone gets hired from the outside to do the job you were doing so as to "relieve you from these duties" also.. you would have to train them. The union has too limited a reach so it can't protect you from the micromanaging motherf***ry of your superiors the HR methods are too opaque to be engaged with. ex.: the yearly reviews are so complex, you need training to do your review and even then, you're not sure to understand. Benefits are low, no glasses in a university is stupid

review_title: A high price for a degree
job_title: Ph D Student in Montreal, QC
pros:
It's a reputable, well-known university in North America and a hub of advanced research. There are multiple collaborations between industry and the university which makes it easier to find internships. If you wish to move onto industry work there are several programs here to serve as a launchpad.
 
Montreal itself is a vibrant city with lots of opportunities for career progress, especially for biotechnology and sciences. It's young and hip and a lovely place to live in.

McGill student services are decently organized as far as the nationwide standards go. As it is an English-speaking university, it's easier to access services on campus even if your French isn't great. 

It's a large university with a lot of interdisciplinary programs, which I believe is the future of all academia. Gone are the days where a Ph.D. meant getting expertise in a very narrowly defined area with the hope of becoming a professor. Ph.D.s today are more likely to go on to work outside academia, which makes this university particularly attractive to those who want to gain expertise in multiple fields and skills that would make you a better industry hire.
cons:
All of my cons are focused on the salary. 
The minimum stipend for my program not only has not increased in 10 years but it was actually decreased in 2017. Based on a 40-hour workweek (a laughably low number for most graduate students), the minimum stipend is <55% of the minimum wage. After tuition, your take-home amount is ~50% of the calculated minimum cost of living for a single person in Montreal (based on 2020 data).

Like many North American universities, graduate students here are underpaid, overworked, and undervalued. They are meant to produce research that can make the university money, none of which go towards increased salaries for actual researchers. There are no centralized unions to negotiate salaries across departments and therefore stipends vary widely across the board. There are also little to no legal protections for the labour rights of students (although this is more on the province & country).

It is quite jarring if you come from more organized (and better) universities in Western Europe with legally mandated minimums, labour rights for graduate students and transparent negotiation schemes and tracks for advancement. I have to assume this will eventually lead to a brain drain from NA to the EU.

review_title: Good vacation package, not great pay
job_title: Senior Communications Coordinator in Montreal, QC
pros:
McGill offers a very good benefits and vacation package. You receive Fridays off in the summer, a long break in December, and an additional 3-5 weeks (depending on how long you've been there).

For the most part, it's fairly stress-free and people are nice. Most of the people who work there have spent their entire careers there.
cons:
Because many of the positions are unionized, it's next to impossible to get a raise. In order to get more money or a new title, you'll need to apply to another position. In general, the salaries are much lower in comparison to for instance, Concordia.

This of course depends on the team, but there is a lot of "that's the way we've always done it." With McGill being such a large institution, it's easy to get caught up in processes and not be able to implement new ideas.

pros: Great benefits, room to explore, no one is really demanding much from you.
cons: No one really demands much from you and pace can be a bit slow but that has been my experience with academia in general. Not much room to rise in the ranks. I wouldn't recommend it or not - it really depends on what you're looking for.

pros: good teacher and good student
cons: I do not have any cons

pros: - Flexible to student's study schedule
cons: - Not enough research opportunities for arts students

pros: academic environment is great, profs and students are smart
cons: assignments and exams are difficult

review_title: Overall good experience with the university
pros: Flexibility to work from home
cons: No objective way of performance evaluation

pros: Hard work but learn lots
cons: Competitive environment and lots of work

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Montreal, QC
pros: Flexible time, great learning environment
cons: None really to speak of

job_title: Physics Research Assistant in Montreal, QC
pros: Excellent quality of research produced
cons: Huge power imbalance between supervisor and research assistants

pros: It is an good experience.
cons: none as I currently remembered.

review_title: 3 years in a professional role - still no benefits, vacation or sick days
pros:
Nice buildings
No oversight, easy for workers to slack off
Great if you are a student worker with no financial responsibilities
cons:
No sick days
No vacation days
No benefits
Low Pay
Casualization of the workforce
No official recourse for violations of HR guidelines and constant violation of union collective agreements
Zero job security
No opportunities for career advancement
Incompetent management
Ignorant Human Resources Department

pros: There benefits for full time staff are really good - e.g on top of vacation days that you get, you also get the so called summer fridays. Add to this the vacation days you get between Christmas and New Years and you end up with pretty significant number of paid vacation days. The Mcgill pension plan - the University contributes a pretty big percent that actually goes up as you get close to retirement.
cons: The supplimental health insurance does not cover a lot  - no coverage for glasses. The dental insurance is very basic - if you or your family have dental problems, you will end up spending a lot out of pocket. The year limit was something like 2000.

pros: You have the opportunity to help some of the best and brightest students learn and navigate the university structure.  Within my department, there are a lot of new projects being developed, which makes it a very exciting time to be working there.  Montreal is an amazing city and McGill's location in the centre of downtown makes it a convenient place to work as well.
cons: McGill is an enormous bureaucracy with very few people willing to go out of their way to share information or provide assistance to people outside of their departments.  Because of this, if you are looking for information from another department, you can get bounced from person to person, or even department to department without ever finding a satisfactory answer.  The upper management is not very supportive of lower-level employees and you can definitely make more money at Concordia doing the exact same job.

review_title: There are many fake reviews here
pros: Health and dental benefits. Pension.
cons:
It is the worst-kept secret that McGill is well-known among industry H.R professionals as a bad place to work - difficult to get in but very easy for the door to be shown to you.

A highly negative  work environment, extremely low pay for the amount of responsibility some jobs require especially when you compare it to similar positions in the private sector. It might be alright for academics and research associate types but for managers and administration, the place is a mess, further compounded by various unions who do not help matters at all.

pros: Relaxed environment, definitely not a pressure cooker, gives you more time to explore and go off on work-related side projects. Fantastic campus, especially in summer. McGill's reputational standing is pretty astounding. Montreal is a totally awesome city too!
cons: Relaxed environment breeds inefficiencies. Some units and departments are plagued with cronyism and politics (while others are fine). Resources are sometimes very thin and you make do with whatever you have. McGill's red tape is legendary. Depending on where you happen to be, your office could be new and modern, or totally decrepit. If your building looks like a 18th century grand chateau/Victorian mansion on the outside, be prepare to live like the 18th century inside too.

pros: Location, good benefits, students are great to work for, some faculties I heard are good to work for
cons:
The Faculty of Management at McGill is extremely toxic and I would avoid working here at all costs. Turnover is high. People are leaving because the environment is so bad across all departments, you name it. 

High level of bureaucracy, slow and poor decision making, lack of top-down transparency, unethical HR practices, major salary discrepancies between employees which don’t match the role, big push to find the cheapest employees to cut costs, no opportunities for advancement and finally, a Dean who doesn’t even say hello... elitist and has her own agenda... which doesn’t include appreciation for personnel.  Apart from her inner circle, you will never see her, nor will she know you or care to know you.

There are people in management positions here who come and go as they please, get paid to do absolutely nothing with zero accountability.

review_title: Excellent faculty, great support for PhD students, a great value.
pros: You get to work with world class faculty in a world class city.  For Americans, its an international experience without having to go too far.  They support their PhD students well and TA remuneration is quite competitive.
cons: The budget ax is always swinging as Quebec is deeply indebted. Building are a bit old and sometimes lack amenities.  The campus is quite small for the number of students that attend McGill and it is difficult to reserve space. The unions can be a bit over-zealous at times.

review_title: If you're more into job security than professional development, this is the place for you.
pros: Awesome benefits, flexibility, a competitive salary and great job security with amazing colleagues. If you have a managerial mindset, you can go very far, fairly quickly.
cons:
Lack of mentorship, recognition and professional development for rank and file employees. However, perhaps that's to be expected because of almost tri-annual restructuring, with groups being renamed and shuffled off to different departments.

Usual issues with larger institutions: impossible to be at the forefront when your main task is to maintain and support older, proprietary systems.

pros: Excellent facilities and services for the employees, great location.
cons: Somewhat poor administration and inefficient process such as appointment and salary/stipend handling, expense reimbursement, etc.

review_title: Great way to learn, but would have needed more specific outline of responsibilities
pros: Was a great way for me to gain some teaching experience, and refresh my knowledge on some of the skills I hadn't used in sometime before this position.
cons: The workload distribution sheet that determines how you get paid can be vaguely filled out and often times things can take a lot longer than people will admit to. So If the previous TA agreed to so many hours to grade papers, the next TA is excepted to have the same number of hours, regardless of the class size. It got hectic, but it was specific to my department. Many other TAs don't have this issue, but I learned too late that something could have been done about it all.

pros: McGill is a serious work-place where you have plenty of upward mobility and lifetime employment security.  There are plenty of places to move around to if you don't really like your department and the environment is pretty collegial.
cons: It's a trap for anglos in Montreal.  If you are a unilingual anglo and you work here, you will be unemployable anywhere else due to the fact that you will never practice your French enough to work in a French environment.  If you ever become bored with your job, you'll be stuck, which will eventually breed resentment and force you to consider either sucking it up or leaving the province.

review_title: Lots of time off, not a tonne of money to use during said time off.
pros: Generous vacation.  Three weeks to start, four weeks after three years, five weeks after seven years.   Employees also get paid holiday break during Christmas season and approximately nine Fridays of paid time off during the summer.  Sick leave can be used to care for family members as well.
cons: Salaries are low compared to other universities in the city with similar benefits.   Atmosphere can feel very corporate with little room for growth.   Change resistant culture at times.

review_title: Great University, on the decline due to budget cuts
pros: very smart people. cosmopolitan city. good atmosphere. looks good on your CV. I recommend it. I received good compensation, although from what I see around me that is not usually the case. The cost of living in Montreal is low relative to big cities in north America.
cons:
many temptations around keeping you from your work... (though it can be a plus).
Budget cuts effect funding opportunities, and staff cuts means more admin and technical work left to the PI, and subsequently his students and postdocs. Oh, and winter is long and cold.

review_title: McGill is a world class university with incredibly talented professors with whom it is an honor to work with
pros: World class research, great teachers, and in an amazing city
cons: McGill has the potential to be the best in the world, but French-English politics has meant that McGill is underfunded and its infrastructure is crumbling because of it. This means loss of innovation and profit for Quebec. If only our government would appreciate the role of university in enhancing our everyday lives.

pros: Quite organized and very good student support system (self-development courses, councelling, career service). Lot of talks from researchers all over the world. Nice campus (downtown).
cons:
From a student point of view, no cons really. 
From a principal investor point of view,  I could see that  private construction contractors repeatedly damaged our building and management of construction work in general is loosely organized, workers do a bad job and due to this, many working hours in our institute were lost. This is a general problem for Quebec though. Also over-complication of the systems like ordering equipment to the institute, etc.

pros: The location of McGill is excellent, in the center of very cosmopolitan Montreal.  The international reputation of McGill was my motivation for working there.  Your experience will be mostly what you make of it.  For bright people, I think it is an environment where they can excel.
cons:
The major downsides of McGill is the aging infrastructure around the main campus and the notorious red tape associated with administrative issues.

The quality of your experience at McGill is mostly related to your direct management.  So the advice for graduate students is to do some research and to chose your advisor carefully.

pros: Interesting and knowledgeable people. Most work places are located in the city center on a nice campus. McGill health research is broad and is located in several hospitals and institutes.
cons: Talking about work is more important than doing work. Many employees are not self-startes and the research groups are often not very dynamic. Research assistants are underpaid, overworked and often frustrated. Medical doctors and professors are overrated and overpaid. This is - at most - an average university in health research. However, due to its diversity of groups and institutes there are still many exeptions.

pros: Lots of time off (Summer Fridays, 12 stats, 4 weeks vacation). If you get in the right department it is a nice life. Campus is beautiful, right downtown. Students are fun, multi-cultural and this adds a great dimension to the campus. Lots of your peers are great people.
cons: Too many layers, HR department is not qualified as they are simply people who have been at McGill a long time and worked their way up. Too many departments/faculties are chaired by academics who have no idea of how to "run a business" or manage people. Faculty usually live in their research world.

job_title: Senior Project Manager and Special Projects Director in Laval, QC
pros: Excellent work hours.  Fridays off in the summer.  Access to several free career development courses.  Downtown Montreal.  Opportunities to move within the university in to other departments.  Great employees!
cons: Very bureaucratic.  In the more recent years, poor leadership from executive administration.  Senior managers micro-manage their staff and provide no room for personal growth.  Do not have confidence in the employees and are quick to misjudge circumstances.

pros: Very understanding towards student-employees, plenty of perks and benefits such as on-the-clock expenses being refunded. A relaxed ad-hoc system of administration, which makes each contributing worker feel welcomed, equally important and comfortable to voice their opinions and ideas.
cons: Perhaps not as strongly admired on a Resume unless the positions are top-notch. Furthermore, would have liked to see more tangible forms of recognition regarding contributions and work for lower-rung, but valuable services being provided by student-workers.

pros: Respectful environment, multicultural environment, ability to plan your own time, you have control over how to convey and display information, hourly pay is good, your supervisor does not interfere in how you handle student affairs and unpleasant situations. It's all up to you!
cons: Campus located far from downtown, you are not given enough hours to work even though the hourly pay is good. There are no benefits attached to this position

review_title: So much potential... but not there yet.
pros: Great benefits. Opportunities for professional development through various HR/OD initiatives.
cons: It's a research-focused university that is not nearly as student-focused as it should be. A lot of people work at McGill because they can/because they have been for years and they have job security... not because they believe in what they are doing or because they enjoy working with students.

review_title: Good for academia, but limited professional outlook
job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Montreal, QC
pros: Tons of expertise in many fields (Biology, Chemistry, Engineering, Medicine, management/finance).
cons: Length of degree in the Sciences (The average is 6+ years for many departments in health/pure and applied sciences), low stipend level (and a stipend is not always guaranteed in some departments - check before accepting admission). School places a large focus on academic success, but does not cater well to PhD students wishing to work outside academia upon graduation.

job_title: ICS Tech Support in Montreal, QC
pros: Lots to learn if you work in the right department. Good benefits. Working with intelligent people.
cons: Lots of nepotism between management and employees. If you work hard it is not valued here by management. Raises are limited and potential promotion non-existent. Cooperation between departments very limited by bureaucracy. Do not work in tech support, management lies and exploits its workers. Suggestions for improvement are ignored or responded to with warnings.

review_title: perfect for undergrad training but not for grad training anymore
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Montreal, QC
pros: McGill still offers great deal of research sources and recent investment in proffesional development.
cons:
Salary pay rate is recently dropped down to 13th place among Canadian institutes. Once "Harvard of Canada" cannot pay top salaries and cannot offer guaranteed admission for graduate students and very limited funding opportunities for postdocs. 
Recent changes in minimum salary requirements of grad students and postdocs at MUHC (McGill University Health Centre) affiliated labs, there is no minimum requirement anymore, so any PI can pay grad student or postdoc anything they want, even lower than McGll University recommendations.

review_title: Good place to start engineering/academic career
job_title: Post Doctoral Research Fellow in Montreal, QC
pros: Nice, young spirited team as you get to work alongside master and phd students. Great exchange of helpful and enlightening discussions. If the GPA score is perfect, there's lots of different funding opportunities. In close proximity to everything, right at Downtown Montreal.
cons:
Really depends on your professor. A lot of freedom may also mean sometimes lack of leadership from your supervisor, which can mean that you're completely by your own. 

Often luck of collaborations within the group or department. This may result in repetitive work among colleagues who may sit just two meters away from each other.

pros: Working at the bookstore is pretty great. They are very flexible with your hours and do not give you many responsibilities, other than keeping the sales area neat and shelving any new merchandise. Great place to work over all.
cons: No challenges really, obviously that managers do not listen to you if you have any ideas, cannot really put any of your ideas into the job.

pros: The hours were very flexible and McGill University cares well about your well being so you were given many opportunities to take a break and rest. My colleagues were generally very friendly and helpful to one another.
cons: There is nothing bad to be said about this job, everything from the interview to the actual position went exceptionally well. Some of your clients might get angry but...

job_title: Student Affairs Coordinator in Montreal, QC
pros: If you are lucky to get a professional and ethical manager then you have good perspectives.
cons: If you get to have a jerck instead of a good manager then you better leave.  Your hard work and tons of overtime will not count. Your honest feedback to the HR manager will not count.  All the managerial knowledge that you may learn as student may remain not applicable. All because your imediat manager has too much power even you may see this person 2 if 3 times in 6 months, when in fact should not if you have ten other people you work and connect daily and who may confirm you are different then your immediate jerk.

pros: Small classes, really engaged students, great place to be. The labs are pretty good and most people are very friendly and helpful. Good work/life balance.
cons: The main downside to being at McGill is the constant construction. The entire campus is constantly under construction, as well as all the streets around it. TA's also typically put in far more work than they are paid for.

pros: I've been volunteering at the McGill biochemistry lab, filing invoices for purchased equipment. The staff is very friendly and people are interesting and nice to talk to.
cons: If you are only francophone, it might be challenging as the majority is anglophone. There were not a lot of places around my building to go for lunch, so I had to bring my own. But it's not true for every McGill building.

pros: Very good place to work, great people, good evironment. Benifits and training is really good as well. Very understanding employer and overall very respectful.
cons: Unless you change departments or wait for someone to retire, there is almost no movement for advancement.  Very hard to show your worth when you are not given opprotunity to try something new.

review_title: Really great depending on what department you work for!
job_title: Lead Peer Advisor in Montreal, QC
pros:
I was given the opportunity to suggest new things and learn on the go.
The job was part-time and I could do the hours whenever I had the time or when we would have an event to plan.
cons: I wish there was even more to do in the office since it was great to interact with colleagues while I was there.

pros: Benefits, pension plan, paid summer fridays, paid personal days and floaters, paid vacation, reasonable work hours, highly accessible by public transportation, beautiful campus, strong work/life balance, plenty of opportunity for lateral movement
cons: Lack of recognition for clerical staff, relatively bureaucratic and slow moving, processes in need of some innovative and fresh ideas, lack of  emphasis on employee skill development, opportunities for advancement may be difficult to come by, average salaries, communication limitations between senior management and admin support/clerical staff.

review_title: Worked at the McGill Bookstore. Easiest job I have ever had.
pros: I got paid. Not very much, but it helped. Training took about four minutes. The other students working there were chill. Would recommend keeping your phone on you - it can get a little boring.
cons: I was a cashier. I sold books. I wasn't very good at counting (read: I was lazy), so I would usually just round up to the nearest dollar. Whatever.

review_title: It's a stable place, but not for everyone
pros: Great benefits -lots of vacation time, and one can be quite independent depending on Faculty/department that you are working in. Lots of work-life balance
cons: Bureaucracy to the maximum!! sometimes you feel like you're stuck in the 70's in terms of management mindset.  If you're a hard-worker you might be too fast for the place

pros: If you have a good scholarship and supervisor it's a nice place to be. Lots going on, and lots to learn.
cons: I can be stressful if you have a bad supervisor, support is getting better, but some tenured faculty are quite bad with managing their students and I've seen quite a few relationships go very sour. Make sure to talk with students away from the supervisor before starting in a lab.

review_title: Well-known university with cheap tuition in the heart of a fantastic city.
pros: Great cultural city, great location within city, well-known university, good knowledge transfer, lots of activities for graduate students, cheap tuition, lots of opportunities to practice your French
cons: Cold winters, large university in the center of the city (may not be a great fit for those who prefer smaller college towns), can be hard to get a part-time job outside of school without the ability to speak French

job_title: Part-time Administrative Assistant in Montreal, QC
pros: It's a very good job for a full-time student, providing very flexible hours.  It is also possible to only speak English for the job, something rare in Quebec.
cons: McGIll functions as a very rigid bureaucracy and there is a lot of red tape.  It can sometimes be difficult to make even the smallest of changes to the system.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Montreal, QC
pros: There are a lot of research and teaching opportunities for graduate students at least for the medical science programs.  As well as many recognized researchers.
cons: Compensation for PhDs  slightly higher than for masters students and does not go up with experience.  Might have to devote extra time for emails of students.

pros: Dynamic work environment, diverse age groups, workforce from diverse backgrounds. Laid back environment, easy work.
cons: Slow upward mobility, the work environment has a corporate feel to it, there's visible diversity but the culture of the work environment is conservative and marginalizing. Not environmentally conscious as an institution.

review_title: Interesting job but quite limited by red-tape. Decision making process is long and time consuming with many follow-ups.
pros: Great opportunity to interact with students and academics. In general, the institution offers great atmosphere and some perks, like education reimbursements, so it is a great palce for those who wish to take evening courses and pay less.
cons: It is politically correct and almost a rule that most managerial decisions are communicated or consulted with departments which are only remotely related to yours.

pros: One of the best institutions around the World that offer education in a wide array of disciplines. Truly a place to be.
cons: At times you feel the management asks too much of you and does not remunerate you according to the labor that you put in.

pros: Good benefits, vacation and pension plan.  Good health care coverage and tuition assistance.  Many job opportunities for advancement if new to the job market.
cons: Not much employer recognition beyond seven years of employment.  Maximum 5 years vacation after 7 years onwards.  Work hours may be long during peak periods depending on position held.

review_title: Enjoyable place to work at, with good benefits.
pros: Working for McGill is an enriching and rewarding experience, as you are able to accomplish impactful and meaningful work. Employees are committed to making a positive difference, and there is generally speaking a positive attitude between team members to work together on projects. benefits are also great.
cons: I noticed that sometimes there can be "politics" and bureaucracy to manage.  There is also little place for advancement.

pros:
A true 9-5 job
Flexibility to earn additional degrees to move to a better employer
cons:
Poor opportunities for personal development
Lack of a true culture that defines the university
The work is at best designed for someone out of CEGEP
Most colleagues are lesser educated that you are (ie most of them are CEGEP grads)

pros: The PhD program provides the opportunity to develop cutting edge technology, and in some cases to create your own patents and intellectual property. A small amount of students developed startup companies from their research.
cons: The salary must be used to cover tuition costs and health/dental insurance. This salary is much lower than the average for advanced degrees. Also, it might take a long time to get results to allow you to graduate (up to 6 years).

pros: It takes 3-4 months for McGill administration staff to switch me from Ph.D. student to a postdoctoral fellow. I called them and can not find anyone who can help me. I was an international student before and the international student officer who takes care of visa affair and gave me wrong information for my working visa.
cons: McGill Administration informed postdoc about income impact of paying province tax in very short notice. They even postpone our payroll for two weeks.

pros: Good people, nice salaries, flexibility to work time, good retirement benefits, cheap place to live with attractive montreal city, nice environment to work with.
cons: Did not see any cons; it is only about the city; easier to manage a job with bilingual person in non-faculty positions; but did not find any difference after employment

pros: Great environment to work in, friendly people, great opportunity for higher learning, the benefits are much further reaching the people realize.
cons: Low salary, it is all that I can see, every thing else makes it a great environment for any level of management.

review_title: Relaxed place to work and make some money
pros: The hours are very flexible, the work place is very relaxed, good opportunity to work with fellow students, and enjoyable place to work.
cons: Compensation is below average compared to amount of sales done. Chance of a raise are low and the job can be boring with hours of limited customers.

pros: During my time in McGill, I have many educated people from different countries, studying in different fields, and having pisitive scientific infleunece in the whole world.
cons: The most importmant problem is the campus of McGill uinviersity in the downtown montreal. It is very old fashioned and need to be renovated.

review_title: McGill undergraduate researcher in chemical engineering, worked on a project for four months in the summer of 2013
job_title: Summer Undergraduate Researcher in Montreal, QC
pros: The pros are having a strong peer group, doing relevant work, working with an accessible professor, and flexibility in work schedule.
cons: Downsides are a great amount of expected work for a low salary, occasional issues with lab space and equipment, and a lack of unsolicited direction

pros: Very stable environment, stable hours, everything is done by the book. If you're looking for great work-life balance, this is the place for you.
cons: Too much red tape, too much protectionism for various tasks, very difficult to have someone take responsibility for issues. If you're looking for a non-academic position, it will rarely be working with the same standards as normal businesses.

pros:
McGill has been the top university in Canada for many years.
If you are looking for a research focused environment, this is one of the best places to get a Masters / Ph.D. degree (not only in Canada, but also in the world).
cons:
Permanent positions in research are difficult to get, but this is a problem in the whole world, not just at McGill.
Financial problems have been showing for a while.

pros: McGill will look good on the diploma. It is a world leader in many fields and has many well-known researchers, which will definitely help with getting a post grad school job.
cons: Salary is basically a slave wage and we're expected to work all the time. Graduate school is absurd like that and we have no recourse. It's an endless cycle where professors think they own us because they're paying us pennies.

pros: The flexible work hours, for some as a student working on campus.Especially if you're enrolled in work study. This is a great option for student looking for a part-time job while studying full-time at school.
cons: McGill has had its ups and downs within the past few years, students strikes, cuts to government expenditures. As a results pay is a non-living wage for students and jobs are scarce and competitive.

review_title: I would not recommend this institution, particularly to graduate students.
job_title: Seasonal Instructor, Teaching Assistant, and Research Assistant in Montreal, QC
pros: Being around a lot of extremely intelligent people. The students are for the most part very bright.
cons: The administration is completely tone-deaf, and there is a lot of animosity between teaching assistants and the admin and more recently, students and admin. Graduate students are very underpaid and with the new time-to-completion limitations it seems that McGill is putting money ahead of quality of learning.

pros: Great environment to work in, engaging, top of the field. Always interesting talks being given and brilliant people to speak with.
cons: Professors hire like-minded individuals which can lead to very homogenous labs, sometimes can be very boys-club like or all non-native english speakers. This makes it easy to feel ostracized or hard to get along with peers.

pros: I was working as teaching assistant in McGill University from 2015-2016. The experience was amazing, and I do learn a lot not only from the processors but also from my colleagues. I do appreciate the chance if you have the chance to apply, just apply!
cons: I have to say the salary at that time was too few. When compared to the same positions at other company, it was not competitive.

pros:
Great employees
Summer Fridays
Expectation of excellence
cons:
bureaucratic incompetence
HR is not invested in trying to keep internal top employees
very low pay compared to university peers in city and elsewhere

review_title: McGill University treats its students well BUT...
pros:
- Lots of support for students through various University-run groups and associations
- Many scholarship opportunities
cons: - They expect students to be able to survive on as little as 14 000 CAD per year, many of whom work 60+ hour weeks making it impossible to have another job on the side

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Montreal, QC
pros: Vibrant atmosphere. Professors (most of them) are super encouraging. Guidance at each stage of PhD by not just the supervisor, but by the entire advisory committee. Help with CV writing cover letter writing and job search (McGill Caps rock!). Montreal is a great city for students.
cons: Food in most McGill cafeterias are expensive.

job_title: Casual Research Assistant in Montreal, QC
pros: Good staff, good co-worker, good environment
cons: Casual research assistant gets paid by filling out timesheets by hand and submit to the supervisor, and sometimes the supervisors forget to submit your timesheets or admin enter the wrong number of hours. You have to pay close attention to your payroll every time because it's very likely that they make a mistake.

review_title: Postdoc Experience depends on director, department and funding prospects
pros:
- Location (Montreal)
- Easier logistics
- Research focused (can be if you want it to be)
- Good experience
- Reputation
cons:
- Easier logistics (can be a big con if your director is not a good person)
- Less compensation and benefits than other similar universities
- French Language requirement around the university limits you to the research in the university (McGill is English-speaking) or outside the province.

pros: good benifits, relaxed environment, handling student services and helping students to check out books, organize seminars, provide some assistnace in using reference softwares.
cons: no career progression , not much team work, not very exciting , salary could be better, hours are flexible but rather unstable and management needs to be improved

pros: Generally nice place to work - depends widely on what department you work in.
cons:
Low salaries (depends on position).
Benefits are %50 employee paid and cost about $500 per year.

pros: Interesting work, plus you interact with your professors in a different environment. It looks great on your CV as well.
cons: The pay is not amazing, and it can be tough to balance with your school work. Make sure you know what you're getting into in the beginning.

pros: Easy, not a lot of supervision, good hours, friendly co-workers. In addition to the standard part-time position during the semester I also did it full-time over the summer for two months. Five out of the eight weeks, the supervisor was on vacation and an already laid-back workplace got considerably more so.
cons: absolutely mind numbing; also look forward to getting yelled at by total strangers over the phone.

pros: The department has a good atmosphere and most professors are supporting their students to grow personally and professionally. Students are coming from many parts of the world that makes the day-to-day life very enriching.
cons: The administration may be a bit heavy at times and because the university is downtown, quiet space may be difficult to find on campus during exam time.

job_title: Building Director/Project Manager in Kirkland, QC
pros: Great work environment, fantastic benefice and great work hours. Overall, I recommend working for this university, friendly personnel and highly qualified.
cons: Unionized personnel are often impossible to work with, demands far exceed the management capacity, stressful situation in many occasion.

review_title: Great if you can stand the bureaucracy
pros:
-Great location in the city
-World-class facilities
-People are generally nicer than in industry since this is an academic institution
-Reputation will take you a long way
-Very good work-life balance
cons:
-Constant labour issues
-Convoluted bureaucracy where it takes days to do something that should take 15 minutes
-Not as dynamic as industry for the above reason

pros: Great environment and very good resources (libraries, online services, career and health services). There are many interesting and knowledgeable people who are generally pleasant to work with.
cons: There is some buerocracy and usually work that requires administration takes a long time. Some buildings are on hills so you have to walk uphill every day. In some buildings there is not much choice of food for lunch.

job_title: Surveying Teaching Assistant in Montreal, QC
pros:
-It is an easy and fun job, especially if the weather is good
-You work with other TA's, so the atmosphere is great!
cons:
-You get paid minimum wage, which is not the best
-You start early in the morning (8:00 am I believe)

McGill is not as rich as other universities
McGill is kind of falling behind univerisities such as U of T in research
More rigid language policies in Quebec might affect McGill as an open and international university

Great academic environment

cons: None, really -- downside to working in Quebec is that income taxes are substantial.  Not sufficient for a one-income family.  This is NOT the employer's fault, though.

pros: Great benefits, great environment. This university has thrived and achieved great things in spite of the unfavourable treatments it receives from the Quebec government. The culture is to do more with less.
